intro: Hydrophyllum aldea, commonly known as the bluebell of the prairie, is a flowering plant native to the central United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as prairies and wet meadows. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are blue to purple in color. Hydrophyllum aldea plays an important role in supporting pollinators and maintaining the ecological balance of its native environment.
